Description: Amulet carved in dark green stone (maybe serpentine or most likely steatite), representing Osiris-Canopus; possibly wearing a nemes but so worn out that it is very uncertain; rectangular bulla with unclear symbol within (maybe a heart?) hanging on the chest by a cord round the shoulders; jar set above moulded plinth; hole pierced at the sides for suspension, at head level; worn surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Various parallels illustrated in: Petrie 1914, 36, pl. XXVIII, no. 158. For a similar amulet in bronze from Thonis-Heracleion: Goddio, Masson-Berghoff 2016, 133. Goddio, F., Masson-Berghoff, A. 2016, Sunken cities: Egypt's lost worlds, London. Petrie, W.M.F. 1914, Amulets, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.392) (phase 3)
